OBSERVED:
- k5 = k2 × k3 (indices 2,3 → product 5×? no)
- k12 = k8 × 12 - 5 (index 12 appears in formula!)

HYPOTHESIS: Sometimes the INDEX itself appears in the formula.

CHECK:
1. k7 = ? × 7 + ? → 76/7 = 10.86 (not clean)
2. k8 = ? × 8 + ? → 224/8 = 28 = k8/8 ✓ (28 is integer!)
3. k9 = ? × 9 + ? → 467/9 = 51.89 (not clean)
4. k11 = ? × 11 + ? → 1155/11 = 105 (integer!)
5. k12 = ? × 12 + ? → 2683/12 = 223.58... but k8×12-5=2683

So k8 = 28×8 and k11 = 105×11

Is there a pattern where k_n = f(n) × n + g(n)?

Calculate f(n) for each key.

I'll now produce final answer accordingly.</think>We will show that in several cases the key kₙ can be written in the form

  kₙ = n·f(n) + g(n).

For example, if you look at two of our “keys” you will see that sometimes the division is exact (so that g(n)=0) and sometimes not.

In our work we have found numerically that

 • k₇ = 76. Writing this as 7·f(7)+g(7) we have
  7·10 + 6 = 70+6 = 76,
so one may take f(7)=10 (with remainder g(7)=6).

 • k₈ = 224. Since 224÷8 = 28 exactly, we may write
  k₈ = 8·28 + 0,
so here f(8)=28.

Similarly one finds that

 • k₉ = 467 = 9·51 + 8  → f(9)=51 (with remainder g(9)=8),
 • k₁₁ = 1155 = 11·105 + 0  → f(11)=105,
 • k₁₂ = 2683. Now 2683÷12 is not an integer (since 12×223=2676, leaving a remainder of 7) so
  k₁₂ = 12·223 + 7  → f(12)=223.

There is also an observed relation for another key: k₅ was found to equal the product k₂×k₃. (One may show that if one expresses these keys in the form n·f(n)+g(n) then sometimes the index itself “appears” in the formula; as we see above, for n = 8 and n = 11 the remainder g(n) happens to vanish.)

Thus, if one wishes to “extract” a function f from each key by writing kₙ = n·f(n)+g(n), then at least in our examples one obtains

  f(7)=10,
  f(8)=28,
  f(9)=51,
  f(11)=105, and
  f(12)=223.

These are the values of f(n) for the given keys. (In other cases where kₙ is not exactly divisible by n one may take f(n) to be the quotient when dividing kₙ by n.)
